conclusion: There are four objects above the slabs, illuminated by a light source, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The problem involves analyzing how the shadows A, B, C, and D will change in position and size when the light source moves backward above the objects.
A (paper): The shadow is short, indicating the light is close to the object.
B (ball): The shadow is small and round, indicating the light is close and directly above the ball.
C (cylinder): The shadow is elongated, indicating the light source is at a lower angle.
D (waffle): The shadow is defined and slightly elongated.

premise: As the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light and the objects.
conclusion: This generally results in smaller shadows because the light rays are more parallel.

premise: The light source moves backward, changing the angle of illumination.
conclusion: A (paper): The shadow will move further away from the paper and become smaller and more defined.

conclusion: B (ball): The shadow will move slightly further from the ball and become smaller.

conclusion: C (cylinder): The shadow will move further away from the cylinder and become smaller and more elongated.

premise: The light source moves backward, changing the angle of illumination.
conclusion: D (waffle): The shadow will move further away from the waffle and become smaller and more defined.

conclusion: The shadows (A, B, C, D) move further away from their respective objects and become smaller and more defined.
